 You know, to examine any biological system, be it of a disease or whatever, from an evolutionary perspective, one has to accept evolution as a reality. You don't necessarily have to believe that any particular mechanistic theory of how evolution happened is pertinent to your system, but you have to accept the principle that gene pools change with time, often in response to environmental pressures through natural selection, and they change the properties of species.
 
 If you believe that species are fixed entities with immutable essences (e.g. biblical kinds or baramin), then you can't study evolutionary biology, or explain why that species came to look as it does, with the relatives it has. You can't really explain anything interesting about why it came to be.
 
 In practice, there are very few religious fundamentalists in science, and they are especially hard to find in the biological sciences. The mindsets are simply incompatible.
